page.title: 10ECOLOGY OF THE AREA
page.content: The area flourishes with wildlife. One can see many, now relatively rare wild flowers, in abundant patches throughout the area: cowslips, primroses, bluebells, orchids, and harebells. In the Autumn you can collect sloes, hazel nuts, mushrooms elderberries and blackberries.Evidence of badgers, foxes, deer, rabbits and grey squirrels are found regularly. A pair of grey squirrels are daily visitors to the school grounds where there are many lime trees for them to play and hid in. They have a dray in a nearby garden and recently two baby squirrels were seen in the playground. Sparrow hawks are a frequent silhouetted over head. House martins return each year to nest under the eaves of the school roof. Owls hoot in the evening and cuckoos are heard every spring.
